subject: Filtering of JUnit tests (was: Re: [junit] Suite() method.)
msgSnippet: Hi All, from the testing activity in Netbeans open source project (http://www.netbeans.org) I got the strong requirement for filtering developed tests.
messageBody:
Hi All,

from the testing activity in Netbeans open source project
(http://www.netbeans.org) I got the strong requirement for
filtering developed tests. Netbeans QA & RE departments
required ability to define subset of existing tests, which are
stable enough to be executed continuously and whose
potential failure will discover real regression in Netbean's product.

Well, that was my motivation for writing JUnit extension allowing
test filtering. The idea was simple: assign filter to each test in the
suite and let it decide if it can or can not run depending on its name
and assigned filter.

Implementation was surprisingly simple too:

* there is new class junit.framework.Filter, which you can
set list of include and exclude patterns, each pattern is wildcard-like mask

* the Test interface was extended by functions:
public void setFilter(Filter)
public boolean canRun()

* all classes implementing Test were updated, it means
TestCase, TestSuite, TestDecorator; their behavior is as follows:

TestCase - uses filter for decision if it can or can not run (doesn't run if it
can't)
TestSuite - always can run (ignores filter), but delegates filter to contained
tests
TestDecorator - delegates decision on filtering to decorated test

* doing that should keep as much as possible of existing testing code
working, as it should be derived from above three classes (all you need
is to recompile your tests)

* and finally, new FilteredTestRunner was added to allow test filtering

And now, the reason of this mail, I would like to share my
code with community as there are still voices asking for
something similar.

Attached ZIP-archive contains all of my code and simple example,
which will demonstrate the feature. I have included source files only,
but there is simple Ant's script, which will build all for you, just
follow these steps:

1. unzip attached archive somewhere to your disk
2. write 'ant' to build JUnit extension, this should create lib/junit-f.jar
file
3. copy junit.jar (JUnit 3.6 or 3.5 frameworks) to created lib directory
4. write 'ant example' to compile and start example of tests, you should
get output like this:
Buildfile: build.xml

e-compile:
[javac] Compiling 2 source files to V:\work\jj\example\tested
[javac] Compiling 4 source files to V:\work\jj\example\test

example:
[java] .testGreeting1
[java] .testGreeting2
[java] .testHello
[java]
[java] Time: 0.032
[java]
[java] OK (3 tests)
[java]

BUILD SUCCESSFUL

Note, that three tests were executed.

5. enable filter in build.xml file (comment line
<arg line="RootSuite"/>

and uncoment line
<!-- <arg line="RootSuite -i *Greeting* -e *2"/> -->

and write 'ant example' again, you should get following output:
Buildfile: build.xml

e-compile:

example:
[java] .testGreeting1
[java]
[java] Time: 0.016
[java]
[java] OK (1 tests)
[java]

BUILD SUCCESSFUL

Note, that tests contained in RootSuite class were filtered
by active filter '-i *Greeting* -e *2', thus only testGreeting1
was executed.

That's the demonstration, please try it and let me know.
I am looking forward your comments!

Good luck,
Vita

P.S.: If you don't have Ant already installed, you can
download it from http://jakarta.apache.org.

P.P.S: For those really interested I have refectored Ant's
junit task to support filtering of tests.
